document.masterDocTitle: Phylogenetic placement of Carrhotus Thorell, 1891 with three new species from Sri Lanka (Araneae: Salticidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Phylogenetic placement of Carrhotus Thorell, 1891 with three new species from Sri Lanka (Araneae: Salticidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: National Institute of Fundamental Studies, Hantana Road, Kandy, Sri Lanka.
National Institute of Fundamental Studies, Hantana Road, Kandy, Sri Lanka.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Carrhotus viduus
–
Thorell 1891: 142
. —
Andreeva et al. 1981: 103
, figs 39–42. — Prószyński 1984 a: 16; 1992b: 169, fig. 7. —
Caleb et al . 2020: 61
, figs 57–73, 76–78, 80–82.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Males of this species are distinguishable by the presence of white longitudinal stripes on the carapace and abdomen, as well as the relatively larger retromarginal cheliceral tooth. The palpal conformation of
C. viduus
closely resembles that of
C. taprobanicus
; however, it can be distinguished by the longer, ventrally projecting embolus and its oval base ( Fig. 16A ). Further, the RTA is less slanted ventrally in
C. viduus
( Fig. 16A–B ). Females can be separated from those of
C. taprobanicus
by the broader ML and longer CD and FD ( Fig. 16C–D ). Females can be readily distinguished from those of
C. silanthi
by the kidney-shaped spermathecae ( Figs 12C–D , 16C–D ).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Plexippus viduus C.L.
Koch, 1846: 2
♂♂; depository unknown. Our identification is based solely on the description and illustrations of Prószyński (2009) . He mentioned two possible specimens currently deposited in ZMB. However, their geographic origin is ambiguous (see Prószyński 2009 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
According to
Sudhin et al . (2021)
, C.
tholpettyensis Sudhin, Nafin, Caleb & Sudhikumar, 2021
differs by the absence of a pair of white longitudinal stripes found on the abdomen of male
C. viduus
. The mentioned minor gentilic differences could easily be attributed to intraspecific variation. Thus, we consider
C . tholpettyensis
as a possible junior synonymy of
C. viduus
.

MEASUREMENTS. TL 6.85, PL 2.58, PW at PLEs 2.31,AL 1.35,AW 0.87. Eye field: diameter of AME 0.28; ALE 0.18; PME 0.1; PLE 0.14; PME–PME 0.82; PLE–PLE 0.84; ALE–PME 0.32; ALE–PLE 0.42. Leg I: Tr 1, Fm 1.3, Pt 1.6, Tb 0.8, Mt 0.6; Leg II: Tr 1.12, Fm 1.1, Pt 1.06, Tb 0.7, Mt 0.42; Leg III: Tr 1.1, Fm 1.12, Pt 1.4, Tb 0.52, Mt 0.3; Leg IV: Tr 0.76, Fm 0.52, Pt 0.82, Tb 0.84, Mt 0.52.
PALP. Dark brown; embolus short and thick with blunt tip; bulbus with PLP; RTA only slightly bent ventroapically, curved and claw-like ( Figs 15E–F , 16A–B ).

MEASUREMENTS. TL 5.5, PL 2.04, PW at PLEs 1.95, AL 2.64, AW 2.16. Eye field: diameter of AME 0.48; ALE 0.26; PME 0.12; PLE 0.24; PME–PME 1.5; PLE–PLE 1.46; ALE–PME 0.44; ALE–PLE 0.78. Leg I: Tr 1, Fm 0.92, Pt 0.94, Tb 0.56, Mt 0.38; Leg II: Tr 1.2, Fm 0.78, Pt 1.1, Tb 0.7, Mt 0.46; Leg III: Tr 1.3, Fm 0.8, Pt 1.02, Tb 0.6, Mt 0.42; Leg IV: Tr 1, Fm 0.74, Pt 1.1, Tb 0.4, Mt 0.32.

caption.paragraph:
Fig 15 .
Carrhotus viduus (C.L. Koch, 1846 )
. A–B . Male habitus. A . Dorsal view. B . Ventral view. C–D . Female habitus. C . Dorsal view. D . Ventral view. E–F . Palp. E . Ventral view. F . Retrolateral view. G . Epigynum, ventral view. Abbreviations: E = embolus; PEB = posterior epigynal border; PLP = posterior lateral protrusion; RTA = retrolateral tibial apophysis; TE = tegulum. Scale bars: A–D = 2 mm; E–F = 0.2 mm; G = 0.1 mm.

Fig 16.
Carrhotus viduus (C.L. Koch, 1846 )
. A–B . Palp. A . Ventral view. B . Retrolateral view. C–D . Epigynum. C . Ventral view. D . Dorsal view.Abbreviations:AG = accessory gland; CO = copulatory opening; E = embolus; FD = fertilization duct; ML = mid line; PEB = posterior epigynal border; RTA = retrolateral tibial apophysis; S = spermatheca; TE = tegulum. Scale bars: A–B = 0.2 mm; C–D = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
EPIGYNUM. Structure of epigyne of
C. viduus
( Figs 15G , 16C–D ) resembles that of
C. taprobanicus
but differs in relative proportions of spermathecae, rather elongated and globular in
C. viduus
( Fig. 16C–D ), PEB more curved inwards by forming a prominent central curve, presence of a well-sclerotized midline, margins of CO well sclerotized and shape of CO more prominently C shaped than in
C. taprobanicus
( Fig. 15G ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig 17. Distribution of
Carrhotus spp.
of Sri Lanka.

subSubSection.paragraph:
This species occurs in the mangrove forests in the arid zone and lowland secondary rainforests of the dry and wet zones of Sri Lanka ( Fig. 17 ). Specimens were collected by beating vegetation up to a height of
1– 2 m
.

paragraph.emphasis:
Key to the species of
Carrhotus
in Sri Lanka

paragraph.keyLead:
4. Embolus long, acuminate, RTA as in Figs 11G–H , 12B ................
Carrhotus silanthi ( Caleb, 2020 )

– Embolus short, acute, RTA as in Figs 13F , 14B ...................
Carrhotus taprobanicus ( Simon, 1902 )

5. Embolus tapered, RTA tapered ( Fig. 7D ) ................................
Carrhotus viduus (C.L. Koch, 1846 )

– Embolus bow-shaped, RTA stout ( Figs 6E , 7D ) .......................................
Carrhotus atratus
sp. nov.

7. Spermathecae boat-shaped, CD hook-shaped ( Fig. 7D ) ...........................
Carrhotus atratus
sp. nov.

– ML less prominent ( Figs 13G , 14C–D ) ...............................
Carrhotus taprobanicus ( Simon, 1902 )
